'''Peter McCullagh, [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]]''' is an [[Irish people|Irish]] [[statistician]] and John D. MacArthur [[Distinguished Service Professor]] in the Department of Statistics at the [[University of Chicago]].<ref name=whoswho>{{Who's Who|surname=McCULLAGH|othernames=Prof. Peter|id=U25451|volume=2015|edition=online [[Oxford University Press]]}} {{subscription required}}</ref>

==Education==
McCullagh is originally from [[Plumbridge]], [[Northern Ireland]]. He attended the [[University of Birmingham]] and completed his PhD at [[Imperial College London]], supervised by [[David Cox (statistician)|David Cox]] and Anthony Atkinson.<ref name=mathgene/>
  
==Research==
McCullagh is the coauthor with [[John Nelder]] of ''Generalized Linear Models'' (1983, [[Chapman and Hall]] â€“ second edition 1989), a seminal text on the subject of [[generalized linear models]] (GLMs) with more than 23,000 citations. {{cn|date=March 2015}}

==Awards and honours==
McCullagh is a member of the [[Royal Society]] and the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]]. He won the [[COPSS Presidents' Award]] in 1990. He was the recipient of the [[Royal Statistical Society]]'s [[Guy Medal]] in Bronze in 1983 and in Silver in 2005. 

He was also the recipient of the inaugural Karl Pearson Prize of the [[International Statistical Institute]], with [[John Nelder]], "for their monograph Generalized Linear Models (1983)".<ref>{{cite web|title=The inaugural Karl Pearson Prize|url=http://www.isi-web.org/8736|publisher=The International Statistical Institute|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref> He won a Notable Alumni Award in 2007 from his grammar school, [[St Columb's College]].
